FheFL: Fully Homomorphic Encryption Friendly Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning with Byzantine Users

Yogachandran Rahulamathavan, Charuka Herath, Student Member, IEEE, Xiaolan Liu, Member, IEEE, Sangarapillai Lambotharan Senior Member, IEEE and Carsten Maple, Senior Member, IEEE Y. Rahulamathavan, C. Herath, X. Liu and S. Lambotharan are with the Institute for Digital Technologies, Loughborough University London, London, U.K. (e-mails: {y.rahulamathavan, C.Herath, xiaolan.liu, s.lambotharan}@lboro.ac.uk). C. Maple is with Secure Cyber Systems Research Group, WMG, University of Warwick, CV4 7AL Coventry, United Kingdom. E-mail: CM@warwick.ac.uk. A shorter version of this work was presented in [35].
Abstract

The federated learning (FL) technique was developed to mitigate data privacy issues in the traditional machine learning paradigm. While FL ensures that a userâ€™s data always remain with the user, the gradients are shared with the centralized server to build the global model. This results in privacy leakage, where the server can infer private information from the shared gradients. To mitigate this flaw, the next-generation FL architectures proposed encryption and anonymization techniques to protect the model updates from the server. However, this approach creates other challenges, such as malicious users sharing false gradients. Since the gradients are encrypted, the server is unable to identify rogue users. To mitigate both attacks, this paper proposes a novel FL algorithm based on a fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) scheme. We develop a distributed multi-key additive homomorphic encryption scheme that supports model aggregation in FL. We also develop a novel aggregation scheme within the encrypted domain, utilizing usersâ€™ non-poisoning rates, to effectively address data poisoning attacks while ensuring privacy is preserved by the proposed encryption scheme. Rigorous security, privacy, convergence, and experimental analyses have been provided to show that FheFL is novel, secure, and private, and achieves comparable accuracy at reasonable computational cost.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Fully Homomorphic Encryption, CKKS, Data Poisoning Attack, Privacy attack.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) allows distributed users to learn collaboratively from data, without explicitly exchanging it. This is essential for a number of reasons, including data privacy requirements and regulations that limit the use and exchange of data. In this collaborative learning scheme, each user holds a portion of the distributed training data, which cannot be accessed by the central server (also known as the aggregation server). The users send their local gradients to the server, which aggregates and updates the global model, and then sends it back to the users. However, it has been revealed that sensitive information can be inferred from local gradients [2], leading to the development of privacy-preserving federated learning techniques (PPFL).

The most notable of PPFL algorithms utilise secure aggregation [4, 5, 6, 3], differential privacy [9, 10], and fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) [7, 8]. Each of these techniques has its own benefits and drawbacks which are discussed in Section 2 in further detail. These techniques have been developed to ensure that individual user updates are masked, anonymized or encrypted prior to sending them to the server, preventing the server from inferring usersâ€™ privacy-sensitive information from the local model updates. While these approaches solve the privacy issue related to information leakage, this inadvertently realizes a security threat, known as a poisoning attack.

In a poisoning attack, malicious users sabotage the collaborative learning process by training the local model on fake or rogue data and sending their malicious model updates to the server. If model updates are protected by some of the existing PPFL techniques, it can be easy for malicious users to be successful with a poisoning attack. It should be noted that poisoning attacks are difficult to detect even in non-PPFL settings [11, 12, 13, 14], and hence this is another active area of research in FL. Notable techniques to mitigate poisoning attacks include machine learning to detect outliers [11], clustering using similarities [18] and detecting anomalies [21]; using the performance analysis of global model against local model [22]; gradient clipping [14]; and removing extreme values [13]. It should be noted that these detection techniques require the server to access the usersâ€™ model updates in plaintext, which leads to the initial privacy issue related to information leakage. Therefore, solving privacy issues leads to security issues and vice versa.

In this particular context, we aim to develop a robust mechanism called FheFL that prevents malicious actorsâ€™ intention to corrupt the FL process and ensures that each userâ€™s data remains secure and private throughout the entire process. While there are numerous works that have tried to solve one of the two attacks, only a handful of works in literature have attempted to solve both of these attacks using a single solution [15, 16, 18, 17, 19, 20]. However, as detailed in Section 2, these solutions either rely on two non-colluding servers [16, 18, 20] or collaboration between users [19], or follow all-on-nothing approch i.e., punish the user (or the group that the user belongs to) by ignoring the model updates if the distance between the updated values is high [15, 17]. In contrast to the existing works, FheFL proposes a novel PPFL mechanism that leverages FHE to achieve robustness, security and privacy preservation. Moreover, FheFL utilizes only one server for secure aggregation. We also introduce a recursive weighted update scheme, that works well with FHE, to detect and mitigate the impact of poisoning users without interacting with other user groups, hence overcoming both the all-or-nothing limitations and the need for interaction between users.

2 Related Works

2.1 Security Focused Approaches

FL is vulnerable to poisoning attacks by malicious users. To mitigate these attacks, statistical approaches such as Median [34], Trimmed Mean [34], and KRUM [13] have been developed. The median approach calculates the median of all received model updates and then computes the mean of the updates that are closest to the median. The Trimmed Mean algorithm [34] sorts the model updates based on Euclidean distance. A percentage of updates is then trimmed from both ends to remove outliers. The mean is calculated from the remaining updates, which serve as the global model. This approach balances robustness and inclusiveness in FL, mitigating poisoning data and enhancing model integrity. KRUM calculates the Euclidean distance between a userâ€™s gradients and all other updates, counting the number of times it is among the kğ‘˜k closest updates, and only aggregates the kğ‘˜k most trustworthy updates [13]. Machine learning techniques, such as anomaly detection with principal component analysis (PCA), can also mitigate poisoning attacks [11].

All these approaches enforce the users to send their model updates in plaindomain to the server. Attempting to redesign these algorithms to process the data in the encrypted domain is computationally infeasible. Therefore, we proposed an FHE-friendly secure aggregation scheme in Section 4. The experimental results show that the performance of the proposed algorithm is comparable to the popular schemes.

2.2 Privacy Focused Approaches

In FL, the server can extract sensitive information about usersâ€™ private data from the shared gradients. Users can also orchestrate privacy attacks, but their effectiveness decreases with more participants. Server-side attacks are more potent, especially when the server can trace individual local updates back to their sources [2]. Different types of privacy attacks exist, including membership inference, property inference, distribution estimation, and reconstruction attacks. To execute these attacks, the server needs access to individual local updates in plaindomain.

There are several techniques are developed to thwart privacy attacks. One common approach is using secure aggregation techniques, where the server can only access aggregated model updates, preventing the inference of individual user updates. Bonawitz et al. [4] proposed the first secure aggregation protocol for deep neural networks. In [4], the users need to interact with all other users to generate a secret key between each user pair. Since this approach consumes significant communication bandwidth, a number of recent works [5, 6] have been proposed to optimize the communicational overhead and to compensate for offline users.

One of the issues with the above secret sharing-based schemes is the communication complexity required to execute the secret key-sharing protocol i.e., each user needs to communicate with all other users (or all the users in a group). To overcome this limitation, P. Zhao et al. [3] proposed an elegant solution based on the computational Diffieâ€“Hellman (CDH) problem where each user needs to communicate with its two neighbours only.

J. Ma et al. [7] proposed a multi-user FHE scheme based federated aggregation scheme. The focus of this work is to improve the multi-user FHE scheme suitable for FL settings. On the other hand, J. Park et al. [8] proposed a third-party-assisted FHE-based scheme for FL. In this work, a third party generates pair of a public and private key pairs and distributes the public key to all the users and servers. The users encrypt the model updates using the FHE scheme and public key before sharing it with the server. The server aggregates the model updates from all the users in the encrypted domain. Then it will liaise with the third party to decrypt aggregated model. While this approach doesnâ€™t require secret sharing as in the previous scheme, the scheme requires trust in a third party.

While some methods adopt differential privacy (DP) [9, 10] by injecting noise into local updates before sending them to the server, it should be noted that DP offers reliable privacy guarantees primarily for small values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. A lower Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon value corresponds to a stronger privacy assurance. However, due to the added noise, DP-based FL approaches significantly compromise the overall modelâ€™s accuracy. Consequently, privacy is obtained at the expense of accuracy.

2.3 Security and Privacy Focused Approaches

There are a few notable works that intend to achieve both privacy and security in FL [15, 16, 18, 17, 19, 20]. Table I compares the proposed work and other recent works. The first well-known approach that tackles both the security and privacy issues in FL using a single aggregation server was published in [15]. In [15], each user will be interacting with all other users to compute the distances between their local model against other usersâ€™ model updates using HE for every epoch. Then each user sends its local model updates and the distances to the server for aggregation. The secure-two-party computation between the users at every epoch in [15] adds significant communication overhead and computational complexity to each user.

To offload the communication overhead and computational complexity from the users to the server, the works in [16, 18, 20] utilise two non-colluding servers. In [16], one of the two servers is considered a trusted server that possesses the secret keys of the users. This server can decrypt intermediate encrypted parameters; hence the work in [16] follows a weak security assumption. Moreover, there is a secure two-party computation between the two servers using additively HE using Paillier cryptography.

To overcome the limitations in [16], Z. Ma et al. [18] proposed a scheme called ShieldFL using a two-trapdoor Paillier HE scheme. The ShieldFL also utilises two servers, where the servers need to perform secure two-party computation to detect poisoning users. The Paillier HE-based secure two-party computation in [18] encrypts the gradient vector element by element i.e., if there are mğ‘šm elements in a gradient vector, then there will be mğ‘šm Paillier encryption operations and mğ‘šm ciphertexts. Therefore, for a given security level (e.g., 128-bit or 256-bit security), the Paillier encryption approach used in [18] generates a large number of ciphertexts and consumes a high computational cost compared to single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD) approaches [32]. For the proposed FheFL in our paper, we use CKKS based FHE scheme which exploits the SIMD technique to pack as many plaintext elements in one polynomial hence producing a compact ciphertext with just one encryption.

Recently another work [20] proposed a lightweight FL scheme called LSFL for edge computing use case. The LSFL scheme uses two servers to perform a global model aggregation while preserving the privacy of user model updates via a lightweight randomisation technique. While the LSFL algorithm is the most efficient scheme compared to all other schemes, it relies on a weak security assumption that no users would collude with a server. This is a weak assumption given that there would be a number of malicious users in FL and it is possible for one of the servers to launch a Sybil attack on the LSFL scheme.

To mitigate the two-server architecture proposed in the above works, the works in [17, 19] proposing PPFL schemes secure against byzantine attacks with just one server. The common theme across these two works (similar to the above work in [15]) is to rely on users who communicates with all other users via two-party computations to identify poisoning users. H. Ma et. al. proposed a scheme that uses secret sharing to achieve privacy and commitment scheme, and group-based averaging to detect malicious users [17]. In [17], the quantized neural network has been considered to ensure that the average of the aggregated parameter is within a certain range. If the average falls outside the range, then the update is excluded from the global model. The drawback of this method is that if one user in a group is malicious then the whole group will be excluded from the global model updates. Moreover, since the schemeâ€™s security relies on the users in a small group, the number of users required to collude with the server to compromise a genuine userâ€™s model update is less.

Recently, Jebreel et al., proposed a novel FL architecture called fragmented FL [19]. In [19], a user interacts with another user via a lightweight two-party secure computation scheme to exchange the fragments of the model updates to mix the model updates. Therefore, only around 50% of the elements in the model update vector belongs to the user and the remaining 50% are coming from another user. This approach breaks the link between the userâ€™s training data and the shared model update hence preventing the inference attack by the server. One of the drawbacks of this approach is the communication overhead among the users in every epoch. Moreover, since the server can obtain the aggregated model updates of two users, the number of users required to collude with the server to compromise a genuine userâ€™s model update is just one, hence this schemeâ€™s security is based on weak security assumption. In contrast to existing work, our proposed scheme is designed as a single-server model and eliminates the need for user interaction in each epoch.

3 Background Information

In FL, the training data is distributed across many users and a server would facilitate the collaborative learning process between the users. Based on a problem, the server defines a suitable neural network architecture with a number of layers and neurons. Using this information, the server randomly initiates a global model g0(.)g_{0}(.) and distributes it to all users. Now each user independently retrains the initial model g0(.)g_{0}(.) using its own data, i.e., user uğ‘¢u uses its local training data to calculate the loss between the actual labels and the predicted labels by g0(.)g_{0}(.). Gradients would be calculated based on the loss to update the initial model g0(.)g_{0}(.) into f1u(.)f_{1}^{u}(.). The user uğ‘¢u shares the updated model f1u(.)f_{1}^{u}(.) with the server. Once the server receives the updates from all the users, it gets an average of all the updates to obtain the global model g1(.)g_{1}(.) which is equivalent to 1Uâˆ‘u=1Uf1u(.)\frac{1}{U}\sum_{u=1}^{U}f_{1}^{u}(.). Using g1(.)g_{1}(.), the server initiates the 2nâ€‹dsuperscript2ğ‘›ğ‘‘2^{nd} iteration where user uğ‘¢u now independently retain g1(.)g_{1}(.) using their own dataset to obtain f2u(.)f_{2}^{u}(.). This process is repeated until the model convergence.

It should be noted that the model weights and biases are vectorised prior to sharing with others. This can be easily done by building a long vector by copying all the weights and biases layer by layer. Therefore, let us denote gi(.)g_{i}{(.)} and fiâˆ’1u(.)f_{i-1}^{u}(.) in the vectorised form as ğ iâˆˆâ„TÃ—1subscriptğ ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‡1\mathbf{g}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{T\times 1} and ğŸiâˆ’1uâˆˆâ„TÃ—1superscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–1ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‡1\mathbf{f}_{i-1}^{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{T\times 1}, where Tğ‘‡T denotes the total number of weights and biases. Using this notation, let us denote the global model obtained for the iğ‘–ith iteration as follows:

ğ i=1Uâ€‹âˆ‘u=1UğŸiâˆ’1u,subscriptğ ğ‘–1ğ‘ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–1ğ‘¢\mathbf{g}_{i}=\frac{1}{U}\sum_{u=1}^{U}\mathbf{f}_{i-1}^{u}, (1)

where ğŸiâˆ’1usuperscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–1ğ‘¢\mathbf{f}_{i-1}^{u} denotes the vectorised model update trained by user uğ‘¢u during the (iâˆ’1)ğ‘–1(i-1)th iteration. This iterative process will be terminated when there is no significant improvement to the trained model.

3.1 Attack Models

Privacy attack model : In terms of privacy attacks, we consider a scenario where a semi-honest server participates honestly in the protocol but attempts to extract sensitive information from the private local data of the participants during training. Although participants can also orchestrate privacy attacks based on global models, their effectiveness diminishes as the number of participants increases. On the other hand, server-side attacks are more potent, particularly when the server has access to individual local updates and can trace them back to their sources. Different types of privacy attacks exist, including membership inference attacks that aim to identify if a specific example was part of the training data, property inference attacks that try to deduce specific properties about the training data, distribution estimation attacks that seek to obtain examples from the same data distribution as the participantsâ€™ training data, and reconstruction attacks that ambitiously attempt to extract the original training data from a participantâ€™s local update. To execute any of these attacks, the server requires access to individual local updates. Therefore, our objective is to thwart privacy attacks by preventing the server from obtaining the participantsâ€™ original updates.

Security attack model : In the context of security attacks, the server has no control over the behavior of participants, allowing a malicious participant to deviate from the prescribed training protocol and launch attacks against the global model. Security attacks can be categorized as untargeted attacks and targeted attacks, each with distinct objectives. Untargeted attacks, such as model poisoning, aim to disrupt model availability, preventing the model from converging effectively. In contrast, targeted attacks such as data poisoning via label flipping attacks, focus on compromising model integrity, tricking the global model into making incorrect predictions for specific inputs chosen by the attacker.

In our research, we assume that no more than 20%percent2020\% of the participants in the system can be attackers. Although some studies consider higher percentages of attackers, it is highly improbable to encounter more than 20%percent2020\% attackers in real-world FL scenarios [19]. For instance, in the case of Gboard with millions of users, controlling even a small percentage of user devices would require compromising a substantial number of devices, demanding significant effort and resources, thus making it impractical. Since the targetted attacks (i.e., data poisoning attacks) are subtle and lead to a false sense of security [11], we experiment with the proposed algorithm against targeted attacks involving label-flipping. Furthermore, we assume that the attacker(s) have no control over the server or the honest participants.

3.2 CKKS Fully Homomorphic Encryption

FHE schemes support both addition and multiplication in the encrypted domain [23]. Since Gentryâ€™s groundbreaking work [23], there are numerous improvements were made by several researchers to improve efficiency and scalability. Currently, FHE has reached an inflexion point where several relatively complex algorithms can be evaluated in an encrypted domain in near-real time [25, 26]. Single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD) is one of the powerful techniques that has enhanced the efficiency of FHE by more than three orders of magnitude [27]. While there is a handful of FHE schemes, this paper focuses on the lattice-based Cheon-Kim-Kim-Song (CKKS) FHE scheme [28] since it is the most efficient method to perform approximate homomorphic computations over vectors with real and complex numbers.

The foundation of lattice-based HE schemes, including CKKS, is the Learning With Error (LWE) problem [24]. CKKS FHE scheme is specially designed to support real numbers and suitable FHE candidate for applications relying on vectors of real numbers. CKKS scheme introduced a novel encoding and decoding technique to convert a message ğ±âˆˆâ„Mğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘€\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}, a vector of real values into an integer polynomial xâˆˆâ„¤qâ€‹[X]/(XN+1)ğ‘¥subscriptâ„¤ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘1x\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}[X]/(X^{N}+1) where M=N/2ğ‘€ğ‘2M=N/2 and vice versa. CKKS utilises a residue number system to speed up the computation. In the residue number system, a big integer is split into several small integers, and the addition and the multiplication of the original big integers are equivalent to the corresponding component-wise operations of the small integers i.e., 2q=2q0+q1+q2+â€¦+qL+qL+1superscript2ğ‘superscript2subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘ğ¿12^{q}=2^{q_{0}+q_{1}+q_{2}+\ldots+q_{L}+q_{L+1}} where q0>qi,i=1,â€¦â€‹Lformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1â€¦ğ¿q_{0}>q_{i},i=1,\ldots L, qL+1>qi,i=1,â€¦â€‹Lformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ¿1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1â€¦ğ¿q_{L+1}>q_{i},i=1,\ldots L, and Î”â‰ˆq1â‰ˆq2â‰ˆq3â‰ˆâ€¦â€‹qLÎ”subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ¿\Delta\approx q_{1}\approx q_{2}\approx q_{3}\approx\ldots q_{L}. In CKKS, this Lğ¿L represents the number of multiplications that can be performed to a ciphertext correctly.

4 FheFL: The Proposed Scheme

We propose FheFL, a novel algorithm designed to address privacy and poisoning attacks in FL. To mitigate these threats, we introduce modifications to the CKKS FHE scheme, making it suitable for distributed networks utilising shared secret keys. Additionally, we develop a robust aggregation scheme based on usersâ€™ non-poisoning rate, specifically designed to mitigate data poisoning in the encrypted domain. The fundamental concept behind FheFL is that each user employs a shared secret key to encrypt their model updates using the CKKS FHE scheme and transmits these encrypted updates to the server. By leveraging the homomorphic properties of CKKS, which enable computation on encrypted data, the server can aggregate the model updates from all users within the encrypted domain. Consequently, the resulting aggregated model remains encrypted under the secret key. To facilitate decryption of the aggregated model, each user sends a randomised shared key to the server to reconstruct the secret key from their respective shared secret keys. This cooperative effort enables the server to successfully decrypt the aggregated model. Below we first introduce the proposed aggregation scheme followed by distributed secret sharing scheme, distributed CKKS FHE scheme and necessary encrypted domain functions.

4.1 Non-poisoning rate based aggregation scheme

The fundamental idea of this algorithm is to rely on aggregated global model update ğ iâˆ’1subscriptğ ğ‘–1\mathbf{g}_{i-1} from (iâˆ’1)ğ‘–1(i-1)th epoch as a baseline to judge the model updates ğŸiusuperscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–ğ‘¢\mathbf{f}_{i}^{u} from all the users in iğ‘–ith epoch. The server calculates a squared Euclidean distance duisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¢ğ‘–d_{u}^{i} between ğ iâˆ’1(.)\mathbf{g}_{i-1}(.) and ğŸiu(.),âˆ€u=1,â€¦,U\mathbf{f}_{i}^{u}(.),\forall u=1,\ldots,U as follows:

(6)

The Euclidean distance diusuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢d_{i}^{u} determines how far the model update from the user uğ‘¢u is changed compared to the global model obtained in the previous iteration. The assumption is that this distance will be very high if the model update is poisoned. However, this may not be always true if a user is trying to update the model using novel but legitimate data [35]. Therefore, instead of completely removing the usersâ€™ updates when computing the new global model, we use the weight diusuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢d_{i}^{u} to minimise the impact of the poisoning attack. The intuition is to scale down the usersâ€™ contribution to the global model in proportion to the userâ€™s Euclidean distance diusuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢d_{i}^{u}. If diusuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢d_{i}^{u} is higher then the user uğ‘¢uâ€™s contribution to the global model should be smaller and vice versa.

To reflect the above intuition, let us define a new parameter called the user uğ‘¢uâ€™s non-poisoning rate, denoted as piusuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢p_{i}^{u}, during the iğ‘–ith iteration as follows:

and modify the federated averaging in (1) into a non-poisoning rate-based model aggregation to obtain a global model as follows:

Therefore, we introduce distributed key sharing and multi-key HE algorithms in the following subsections.

4.2 Distributed Key Sharing

Secret sharing is a powerful technique that ensures a secret value can only be obtained when a minimum number of secret shares are combined. We adopt a pairwise secret-sharing scheme where a secret key, denoted as sğ‘ s, is shared among a group of users (Uğ‘ˆU) [31]. Each user (uğ‘¢u) generates its own shared secret, susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u}, such that s=âˆ‘u=1Usuğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s=\sum_{u=1}^{U}s_{u}. To enhance privacy in FL, user uğ‘¢u encrypts its locally trained model using its corresponding shared secret susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u} before transmitting it to the server. The server aggregates the model updates from all users in a manner that the aggregated model remains encrypted but under the secret key sğ‘ s. Decrypting the aggregated model necessitates the serverâ€™s possession of susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u} from each user, but since susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u} is utilized for encryption, it cannot be sent to the server directly. To address this challenge, each user engages in pairwise interactions with other users to generate a unique pairwise secret key between user iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j, denoted as si,jsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—s_{i,j}, where si,j=âˆ’sj,isubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—ğ‘–s_{i,j}=-s_{j,i}.

To assist the server in decryption, user uğ‘¢u transmits sâ€‹su=su+âˆ‘j=1,â‰ uUsu,jğ‘ subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1absentğ‘¢ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘—ss_{u}=s_{u}+\sum_{j=1,\neq u}^{U}s_{u,j}, where the userâ€™s shared secret key susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u} is masked by the pairwise secret keys contributed by other users. The server computes the secret key sğ‘ s by summing all sâ€‹suğ‘ subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ss_{u} as follows:

âˆ‘u=1Usâ€‹susuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆğ‘ subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢\displaystyle\sum_{u=1}^{U}ss_{u} =\displaystyle= âˆ‘u=1U{su+âˆ‘j=1,â‰ uUsu,j},superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1absentğ‘¢ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘—\displaystyle\sum_{u=1}^{U}\{s_{u}+\sum_{j=1,\neq u}^{U}s_{u,j}\}, (10)
=\displaystyle= âˆ‘u=1Usu+âˆ‘u=1Uâˆ‘j=1,â‰ uUsu,jâŸ=0,âˆµsi,jâ£=âˆ’sj,i=âˆ‘u=1Usu=s.superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢subscriptâŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1absentğ‘¢ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘—absent0becauseabsentsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—absentsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ \displaystyle\sum_{u=1}^{U}s_{u}+\underbrace{\sum_{u=1}^{U}\sum_{j=1,\neq u}^{U}s_{u,j}}_{=0,\because s_{i,j}=-s_{j,i}}=\sum_{u=1}^{U}s_{u}=s.

This computation ensures that the aggregated randomised shared secret keys match the original secret key, allowing for successful decryption of the aggregated model. It is important to note that the generation of pairwise secret keys between users only needs to be executed once when a user joins the network. Various protocols, such as the Diffie-Hellman key exchange, can be utilized to generate the pairwise secret keys, and the communication required for this process can be optimized as demonstrated in previous works like [17], although this optimization is not the primary focus of this paper. See Algorithm 1 for more details.

The scalar multiplication requires the multiplication of two encrypted values followed by the addition of encrypted values. Both of these can be done easily using the description provided in Subsections 3.2.1 and 3.2.2. It should be noted that the calculation of [diu]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢[d_{i}^{u}] doesnâ€™t require input from other users therefore, [diu]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢[d_{i}^{u}] is still encrypted under user uğ‘¢uâ€™s shared secret key.

However, to compute the non-poisoning rate [piu]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢[p_{i}^{u}] for user uğ‘¢u as per (7), the server needs to aggregate [diu]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢[d_{i}^{u}]s from all users which are encrypted under different keys. The server can use the randomised shared secret keys from users to retrieve âˆ‘u=1Ususuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢\sum_{u=1}^{U}s_{u} hence it can decrypt and obtain âˆ‘u=1Udiusuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢\sum_{u=1}^{U}d_{i}^{u}. However, individual users squared Euclidean distances cannot be decrypted hence the non-poisoning rate of each can only be calculated in the encrypted domain i.e., as per (7), [piu]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢[p_{i}^{u}] is computed as follows:

[piu]=1âˆ’1âˆ‘j=1Udij.[diu].formulae-sequencedelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢11superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢[p_{i}^{u}]=1-\frac{1}{\sum_{j=1}^{U}d_{i}^{j}}.[d_{i}^{u}]. (12)

In order to compute the global model as in (9), the server first computes [piu].[ğŸiâˆ’1u]formulae-sequencedelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¢delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–1ğ‘¢[p_{i}^{u}].[\mathbf{f}_{i-1}^{u}] which is encrypted under userâ€™s shared secret key. Then it divides it by Uâˆ’1ğ‘ˆ1U-1 to obtain the global model needed for the iğ‘–ith iteration. The pseudocode of the proposed FheFL is shown in Algorithms 1, 2 and 3.

5 Privacy, Security, and Convergence Analysis

First, we establish a set of assumptions that form the foundation of the proposed FheFL scheme and subsequently conduct an analysis of privacy, security, and convergence aspects. We consider a scenario where certain users, referred to as colluding users, collude with both the server and other colluding users. These colluding users not only share their own secret keys with the server but also disclose the pairwise secret keys of other users. It is crucial to note that if there is only one non-colluding user, their model update can be compromised by the server. Therefore, our algorithm mandates the presence of at least two non-colluding users to ensure that only the sum of their respective model updates is accessible to the server. Increasing the number of non-colluding users enhances the level of protection against collusion. For the purposes of this study, we focus solely on data poisoning attacks, where malicious users deliberately retrain the model by introducing incorrect data samples that target specific classes. This type of attack is more detrimental than model poisoning attacks, as the intention is not to render the global model entirely useless, but rather to undermine its performance on the attacked classes while still maintaining reasonable performance on other classes which leads to a false sense of security. Finally, as discussed earlier, we assume a ratio between genuine and malicious users, whereby the percentage of malicious users is limited to 20%percent2020\% [19]. These assumptions provide a theoretical framework and context for the subsequent analysis of the proposed FheFL scheme.

5.1 Privacy Analysis

Corollary 1: To compromise the data privacy of one benign non-colluding user, the aggregating server needs to collude with (Uâˆ’1)ğ‘ˆ1(U-1) users.

Proof: The server needs to compute the sum of âˆ‘u=1Ususuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢\sum_{u=1}^{U}s_{u}, as shown in (10), in order to decrypt the aggregated model. Assuming there are two non-colluding users, n1subscriptğ‘›1n_{1} and n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}, the server has access to keys from the remaining (Uâˆ’2)ğ‘ˆ2(U-2) users, except for sn1subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›1s_{n_{1}}, sn2subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›2s_{n_{2}}, and sn1,n2subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘›2s_{n_{1},n_{2}}. The serverâ€™s objective is to decrypt the model updates, [ğŸin1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–subscriptğ‘›1[\mathbf{f}_{i}^{n_{1}}] and [ğŸin2]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğŸğ‘–subscriptğ‘›2[\mathbf{f}_{i}^{n_{2}}], provided by the two non-colluding users. It is important to note that these updates are encrypted using the CKKS FHE scheme with the respective usersâ€™ keys, sn1subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›1s_{n_{1}} and sn2subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›2s_{n_{2}}, and the server cannot directly decrypt them.

However, the server can obtain the aggregated model and subtract the model updates from colluding users. This operation only yields the sum of the model updates from the two non-colluding users. Similarly, the server computes the sum of the security keys, sn1+sn2subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘›2s_{n_{1}}+s_{n_{2}}. With this information, the server attempts to obtain the individual model updates, utilizing all available information, including the sum of the model updates from the non-colluding users. This allows the server to get the sum of the two non-colluding usersâ€™ model updates. Hence, in order for the server to obtain the individual model updates from either of the two non-colluding servers, it is required to collude with one of them, necessitating collusion with (Uâˆ’1)ğ‘ˆ1(U-1) users.

Let us suppose that the server is successful in obtaining the individual model updates of the users then we can use the server to break the one-time pad encryption scheme which is based on information-theoretic security. We show a security game for this. Prior to that, let us define the information-theoretic one-time pad encryption.

This encryption is information-theoretic secure because if you are given one of the ciphertexts then you wonâ€™t be able to tell whether the ciphertext is encrypting m0subscriptğ‘š0m_{0} or m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} with probability more than 12+Ïµ12italic-Ïµ\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is very small. â– â– \blacksquare

Therefore, if the server can obtain the individual models then it can be used to break the information-theoretic security. For this reason, the proposed scheme protects the privacy of individual user models if there are two non-colluding users. â– â– \blacksquare

5.2 Security Analysis

Corollary 2: The security of the proposed multi-key HE scheme is equivalent to the security of the FHE schemes.

Proof: This proof is straightforward. If there is an adversary who can break the proposed multi-user HE scheme efficiently then the same adversary can be exploited to break the FHE efficiently. We can show this with a simple example. Letâ€™s suppose a message mğ‘šm is encrypted using the FHE scheme as follows: [m]=(a.s+m+e,a)[m]=(a.s+m+e,a). To exploit the adversary, all we need to do is to homomorphically add [m]delimited-[]ğ‘š[m] several times (i.e., the number of users in the distributed network) and send it to the adversary. The adversary receives âˆ‘[m]=[m]+[m]+â€¦=aâ€‹(s+s+â€¦)+m+m+â€¦+e+e+â€¦delimited-[]ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘šâ€¦ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ â€¦ğ‘šğ‘šâ€¦ğ‘’ğ‘’â€¦\sum[m]=[m]+[m]+\ldots=a(s+s+\ldots)+m+m+\ldots+e+e+\ldots which is very similar to the sum in the proposed multi-key HE algorithm. The adversary gets the sum of mğ‘šm, which can be divided to obtain mğ‘šm. Therefore, if an adversary can break the proposed multi-key homomorphic scheme easily compared to the FHE, then this server can be used to break the FHE schemes easily. For this reason, the security of the proposed scheme is the same as the security of FHE. â– â– \blacksquare

5.3 Convergence Analysis

Corollary 3: If the number of benign users is higher than the malicious users then the proposed non-poisoning rate-based weighted aggregation converges to a model which is the same as the benign usersâ€™ only model.

Proof: To prove Corollary 2, let us consider two extreme scenarios. The first scenario assumes that all the users are benign users and the second scenario assumes that all users are malicious. The malicious users are launching a label-flipping attack targeting a few classes. Note that the FL algorithm converges in both scenarios, however, the directions of the final model obtained from both scenarios will be different. Let us denote the global model obtained in scenario 1 as ğ bsubscriptğ ğ‘\mathbf{g}_{b} and scenario 2 as ğ msubscriptğ ğ‘š\mathbf{g}_{m}. We can visualise this using a 2-dimensional example as in Figure 1. However, in a real FL, there will be both benign and malicious users, hence the aggregated model after nğ‘›nth iteration will be a model between ğ bsubscriptğ ğ‘\mathbf{g}_{b} and ğ msubscriptğ ğ‘š\mathbf{g}_{m}. If we denote the fraction of malicious users as Î±ğ›¼\alpha then the aggregated model after iğ‘–ith iteration can be represented as follows:

ğ ai=(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹ğ bi+Î±â€‹ğ mi.superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–1ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘šğ‘–\mathbf{g}_{a}^{i}=(1-\alpha)\mathbf{g}_{b}^{i}+\alpha\mathbf{g}_{m}^{i}. (13)

If the majority of the users are benign (i.e., small Î±â‰ˆ0.2ğ›¼0.2\alpha\approx 0.2) then the aggregated model in (13) will be closer to ğ bisuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{g}_{b}^{i}. Not only Î±ğ›¼\alpha contributes to the aggregated model to be closer to the aggregated benign usersâ€™ model but also the proposed non-poisoning rate-based weighted model aggregation (see Section 4.1) minimizes the influence of malicious users every iteration. In fact, the non-poisoning rate for malicious users will be getting smaller and smaller with the iteration. To explain this, let us denote the non-poisoning rate of benign users as pbsubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{b} and malicious users as pmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{m} then we can modify (13) as follows:

ğ ai=pb.(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹ğ bi+pmâ€‹Î±â€‹ğ miformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘1ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘šğ‘–\mathbf{g}_{a}^{i}=p_{b}.(1-\alpha)\mathbf{g}_{b}^{i}+p_{m}\alpha\mathbf{g}_{m}^{i} (14)

Since the majority of the users are benign, the distance between the aggregated model after each iteration will be increasing against the intended malicious model. This phenomenon can be easily explained using Figure 1. If the aggregated modelâ€™s direction is similar to the solid arrows, then the difference in directions between the solid and dotted arrows are increasing with each iteration. Therefore, the non-poisoning rate of malicious users will be decreasing with each iteration. Therefore, we will have

We validated this proof using experiments in Subsection 6.6.

6 Experimental Analysis

In this section, we report various experimental results to compare the performance of the proposed algorithm against the state-of-the-art algorithms. To conduct this experiment, we have implemented the proposed FheFL algorithm using PyTorch framework and a modified version of the TenSEAL library [29]. We used MNIST dataset and the experiment was conducted on a 64-bit Windows PC with 16GB RAM and Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4210U CPU at 4.1GHz.

6.1 Dataset, neural network architecture, and users

The MNIST dataset contains 70,0007000070,000 handwritten images with digits from 00 to 999. This dataset is split into two: 60,0006000060,000 images for training and the remaining 10,0001000010,000 images for testing the developed model. MNIST is a well-balanced dataset with an equal number of images for each class. The training dataset is split evenly and distributed to all the FL users. We considered 100100100 users in total where 202020 users are malicious and performing data poisoning attacks. For every epoch, the aggregation server randomly selects 101010 users for local model training. Out of 101010 users, two of them are malicious. We considered a simple convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture with two convolution layers and two fully connected layers. We selected an architecture such that the total number of model parameters is sufficient to encode in one plaintext.

6.2 Key generation for CKKS FHE scheme

The security key generation relies on several factors and depends on the underlying application. The high-level parameters Nğ‘N and qğ‘q must be selected by considering efficiency and security. Moreover, the scaling factor 2Î”superscript2Î”2^{\Delta} and a number of multiplication levels Lğ¿L must be set in advance. Since the application might be used by several users, the server presets these parameters common for all users. Given these global parameters (Nğ‘N, qğ‘q, Î”Î”\Delta, and Lğ¿L), each user generates a public key and secret key pair. To achieve 128128128-bit security, we considered two sets of parameters (N=8192,q=218,Î”=25,(N=8192,q=218,\Delta=25, and L=4)L=4) and (N=16384,q=438,Î”=60,(N=16384,q=438,\Delta=60, and L=4)L=4). The proposed FL algorithm requires L=4ğ¿4L=4 multiplication levels. When N=16384ğ‘16384N=16384, we used 60âˆ’limit-from6060-bit precision, and for N=8192ğ‘8192N=8192, the precision has been reduced to 25âˆ’limit-from2525-bit to accommodate 4âˆ’limit-from44-levels of multiplication.

6.3 Robustness Against Data Poisoning Attack

In our experiments, we consider label-flipping attacks where malicious users poison data by changing the labels of particular classes and training the local model. The intention of the malicious participant is to misclassify targeted labels during the prediction stage. In our experiments, we compared the proposed FheFL algorithmâ€™s accuracy against FedAvg [33], Trimmed Mean [34], Median [34] and KRUM [13]. Table II compares the accuracy of the FheFL against all other methods without any attackers.

The results show that when the number of users increases, model accuracy is generally going up. Moreover, the proposed non-poisoning rate-based weighted aggregation scheme outperforms Trimmed Mean [34], Mean Median [34] and KRUM [13] approaches. We also observed that our aggregation technique is slightly better than the FedAvg algorithm when the number of users is equivalent to 100100100. This can be attributed to the non-poisoning rate which smoothes out the gradients which are far away from the intended direction.

Then we tested the robustness of the algorithms in the presence of malicious users. We turned 20%percent2020\% of the users into malicious who perform a label-flipping attack. The malicious users train handwritten images of 777s as ones and 111s as seven. The other classes are not changed. In each epoch, the server expected to select 222 malicious users and 888 benign users randomly. As shown in Figure 2, the proposed aggregation algorithm has converged during the 404040th epoch and became steady during the rest of the epochs and was able to outperform all other popular schemes. Here, the results under different proportions of malicious users are illustrated in Table III. The proposed algorithm outperforms all the popular aggregation schemes in terms of overall accuracy and successfully mitigating the data poisoning attacks. When percentage of the attackers is increasing, the accuracy and detection rate are going down in all the algorithms which is expected.

We also compared the loss of accuracy of the proposed FheFL algorithm due to encrypted domain operations. We used two sets of security parameters i.e., N=16384ğ‘16384N=16384 and N=8192ğ‘8192N=8192. As shown in Figure 3, there is a loss in accuracy compared to the plain domain accuracy (see Figure 2 for plain domain accuracy). When we use a larger ring with N=16384ğ‘16384N=16384 and 60âˆ’limit-from6060-bit precision, the loss of accuracy is less than 3%percent33\% for one-hundred users. When we reduce the ring dimension and precision to N=8192ğ‘8192N=8192 and 25âˆ’limit-from2525-precision respectively, the loss of accuracy doubles. While a smaller ring increases the efficiency as described in the next subsection, it leads to a loss in accuracy. A similar trend was observed in [16] and [18]. In [16], a plain neural network was used and the loss in accuracy between the plain domain and encrypted domain approach is around 4%percent44\%. A simple logistic regression was used in [18] where the difference in accuracy between the plain domain and the encrypted domain is around 3.5%percent3.53.5\%.

6.4 Computational Complexity analysis

Figure 4 shows the computational time required by the server to perform the proposed aggregation in the encrypted domain. It should be noted that the time complexity is measured based on the server that is sequentially processing the usersâ€™ model updates. Calculating the Euclidean distance between the userâ€™s model update and the previous global model in the encrypted domain consumes a substantial amount of processing. However, this operation can be parallelized as it does not depend on the other usersâ€™ input. Therefore, the time complexity shown in Figure 4 can be decreased by the order of the users. Moreover, the computational time almost doubled when the server switches the CKKS security parameter Nğ‘N from 819281928192 to 163841638416384. While smaller Nğ‘N is computationally efficient, this enforces a reduction in the number of bits preserved during the encrypted computation. As shown in Figure 3, the accuracy increases when Nğ‘N is 819281928192.

When N=16384ğ‘16384N=16384, it took around 6 minutes for the proposed algorithm to aggregate model updates from 100 users where the number of elements in the model update is 819281928192. However, as reported in [18], the ShieldFL algorithm requires more than one hour (the specification of the computer used in ShieldFL is very similar to the one we used for this paper). The main reason for this difference is that the proposed algorithm exploits the SIMD technique to pack 819281928192 elements in one ciphertext. The PEFL algorithm in [16] exploits a similar packing technique where it is expected to pack tens of elements in one plaintext, the time complexity can be reduced by around one order compared to ShieldFL algorithm. Therefore, the proposed algorithmâ€™s complexity can be comparable to the algorithm in PEFL [16].

6.5 Communicational Complexity Analysis

Figure 5 compares the bandwidth requirement between a user and the server to communicate the updated model updates for different dimensions of the model updates. Since the schemes in [19, 20] use one-time pad encryption, the bandwidth required to communicate the model updates is significantly lower compared to other schemes. The PEFL scheme in [16] uses packing techniques to reduce the number of ciphertexts required. Therefore, the increase in communication bandwidth requirement for [16] compared to one-time pad encryption is not significant. Also, the bandwidth requirement is increasing linearly with the dimension of the model. The proposed algorithm uses the CKKS FHE scheme and its bandwidth requirement is almost an order higher than the [16]. However, it should be noted that the proposed scheme relies on strong security assumption and rely only on a single server. Nevertheless, each user requires less than 3â€‹Mâ€‹B3ğ‘€ğµ3MB bandwidth every epoch which is not significant given that the training can be conducted over Wi-Fi and/or 5G mobile network connectivity. The ShieldFl scheme in [18] requires almost double the bandwidth compared to the proposed scheme. Moreover, [18] requires two servers, and the communication complexity between them is not accounted for in Figure 5.

6.6 Convergence Analysis

To confirm the convergence analysis proof in Subsection 5.3, we measured training loss against epochs for varying numbers of malicious users. As shown in Figure 6, the training loss is constantly decreasing when the percentage of attackers is small which supports the proof in Subsection 5.3. However, when half of the users become attackers, the proposed model struggles to converge which is expected as shown in the proof. Therefore, if the number of attackers is less than 20%percent2020\%, then the proposed model converges smoothly.

7 Conclusion

In conclusion, the proposed FheFL scheme represents a significant advancement in federated learning by addressing privacy and security challenges. Leveraging FHE, FheFL ensures the privacy of user data by encrypting model updates and preventing privacy leakage. It introduces a distributed multi-key additive HE scheme for secure model aggregation, safeguarding individual user data during the model aggregation process. Additionally, a non-poisoning rate-based novel aggregation scheme combats data poisoning attacks in the encrypted domain. The schemeâ€™s security, privacy, convergence, and experimental analyses validate its effectiveness, offering comparable accuracy with reasonable computational costs while providing robust security guarantees. By introducing a novel framework with a single server and eliminating the need for user interaction in each epoch, FheFL sets the stage for future advancements in privacy-preserving federated learning.
